*Leibovich v. Antonellis*, 410 Mass. 568.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed a duty to Plaintiff’s minor son, A.J., to provide a safe environment, reasonable supervision, and protection from foreseeable harm during activities conducted at its facility.
*Leibovich v. Antonellis*, 410 Mass. 568.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an automobile negligence action and appellate issues about expert testimony, tax instructions, and retroactive application of a loss-of-filial-consortium statute. It does not involve a defendant operating a facility, supervision of a minor during activities, or any discussion of a duty to provide a safe environment or protect a child from foreseeable harm in that context. Thus, it does not address or establish the specific duty described in the proposition.
*Leibovich v. Antonellis*, 410 Mass. 568.relevant_excerpt: On the morning of December 14, 1985, Marc Albert was driving east on Beacon Street in Newton, with Philip Leibovich sitting on the passenger side. Mark Antonellis was driving west on the same street in a pickup truck, approaching Albert’s vehicle from the opposite direction. The accident occurred when Albert attempted to make a left turn and Antonellis’ truck struck the passenger side of Albert’s automobile, severely injuring Philip.

*Akins v. Gillette Stadium Corp.*, 92 Ma.raw_text: *Akins v. Gillette Stadium Corp.*, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 693, 695 (2018).
*Akins v. Gillette Stadium Corp.*, 92 Ma.proposition: Defendant further breached its duty when its staff member disregarded reports of rough play and failed to intervene to prevent foreseeable harm to A.J., in direct violation of *Akins v. Gillette Stadium Corp.*, 92 Mass. App. Ct. 693, 695 (2018).
*Akins v. Gillette Stadium Corp.*, 92 Ma.support_reasoning: The cited Akins v. Gillette Stadium Corp. opinion is a Massachusetts contract interpretation/tax allocation case about value-added tax receivables in a stock purchase agreement. It does not involve negligence, premises liability, duties to supervise, foreseeability of physical harm, or staff intervention in rough play. Therefore it cannot provide authority for the proposition that a defendant breached a duty by disregarding reports of rough play and failing to intervene to prevent foreseeable harm to A.J.
*Akins v. Gillette Stadium Corp.*, 92 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "At issue is the interpretation, under New York law, of a provision in the stock purchase agreement pursuant to which Beam, Inc. (Beam), sold its subsidiary, Acushnet Company (Acushnet). More specifically, the parties disagree as to which of them is entitled to $16.62 million of value added tax (VAT) receivables carried on Acushnet's balance sheet at the time of the closing.... On appeal, Acushnet argues (1) that the motion judge erred, as a matter of law, when she concluded that the contract provision was ambiguous; and (2) that the trial judge's interpretation of the contract was clearly erroneous. We affirm."

*Vasquez v. Greenfield Pub. Sch.*, 484 M.proposition: The Defendant’s failure to adequately train its employees to ensure vigilant supervision and immediate intervention in potentially harmful situations constitutes gross negligence and is supported by *Vasquez v. Greenfield Pub. Sch.*, 484 Mass. 357, 367-369 (2020).

*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.proposition: Defendant's breach of duty was the proximate cause of the harm suffered by A.J., as Defendant could have taken steps to prevent the escalating rough play that led to the incident.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.support_reasoning: The case holds that the landlord had no duty because the criminal attack was not reasonably foreseeable, and thus there was no proximate cause attributable to any breach by the defendant. The opinion explicitly rejects imposing liability where the landowner had no reason to know of a threat against which reasonable preventive steps could be taken. This is the opposite of the claimed proposition that the defendant’s breach was the proximate cause and that the defendant could have taken steps to prevent the incident.
*Whittaker v. Saraceno*, 418 Mass. 196,.relevant_excerpt: “The attack on the plaintiff was not reasonably foreseeable. There was no evidence that the landlord knew or reasonably should have known that a physical attack might occur in the building. … society should not place the burden of all harm caused by random violent criminal conduct on the owner of the property where the harmful act occurred, without proof that the landowner knew or had reason to know of a threat to the safety of persons lawfully on the premises against which the landowner could have taken reasonable preventive steps.”

*Gillespie v. Sears, Roebuck & Co.*, 386.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff individually and on behalf of A.J. suffered damages, including but not limited to medical expenses, emotional and physical pain, lost wages, and loss of enjoyment of A.J.'s normal childhood activities.
*Gillespie v. Sears, Roebuck & Co.*, 386.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns criminal sentencing, postconviction motions under Massachusetts Rules of Criminal Procedure 29 and 30, and appellate procedure. It does not involve a negligence action, does not discuss civil damages, and nowhere addresses categories of damages such as medical expenses, emotional or physical pain, lost wages, or loss of enjoyment of a child’s activities. Therefore it cannot serve as authority for the proposed negligence‑damages proposition.
*Gillespie v. Sears, Roebuck & Co.*, 386.relevant_excerpt: “In this case we address three separate but related appeals. First, the defendant appeals from the denial of his motion to vacate illegal sentences… Second, the Commonwealth appeals an order of the trial judge revising, pursuant to Mass. R. Crim. P. 29 (a)… Third, the defendant appeals from the denial by a single justice of this court of the defendant’s motion to reconsider an earlier order… We address the merits of the Commonwealth’s appeal only, and conclude that there was error.”

*Reinert v. New England Novelty Co.*, 42.raw_text: *Reinert v. New England Novelty Co.*, 428 Mass. 261, 263 (1998).
*Reinert v. New England Novelty Co.*, 42.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that individuals and entities responsible for child care programs owe a heightened duty to ensure the safety of minors due to their vulnerable status.
*Reinert v. New England Novelty Co.*, 42.case_name: Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co. v. Board of Assessors
*Reinert v. New England Novelty Co.*, 42.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with property tax assessment and methods for determining the fair cash value of utility-owned real estate under Massachusetts law. It does not discuss child care programs, duties owed to minors, or any concept of a heightened duty based on the vulnerability of children. The proposition about heightened duties in child care settings is unrelated to the subject matter or holding of this case, so the citation does not support that proposition.

Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 223,.raw_text: Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 223, Sections 1 and 8
Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 223,.proposition: Venue is proper in the Brockton District Court under Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 223, Sections 1 and 8, as the alleged negligence and resulting injuries occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts, and Defendant conducts business in this jurisdiction.

Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 231,.proposition: 2. Prejudgment interest pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws Chapter 231, Section 6B.
